into the<\s> & enter the temporo-sphenoidal lobe  joining with the fibres <s>but their further <\s>
curving to this part of the brain from the anterior commissure.
 <s> connections would require much more detailed <\s>
Their further course would require much more detailed 
description & illustration <s>than would be  <\s> one available 
in the present communication. The subject of the 
composition & connections of the inner & outer capsules 
particularly of the latter is a most complicated 
one & would require a separate treatise for its 
consideration.
[In summing up therefore the origin of the callosal 
fibres in the middle third of the cerebral hemispheres 
I would say that they <\s> [The callosal fibres in the middle third of the cerebrum are derived from all the 
convolutions at the vertex down as far as the 
middle of the operculum. The lower part of the 3d frontal convolution & the margin 
of the operculum, if they contribute in any way 
the formation of the corpus callosum, do so by sending to it 
only a very few fibres. I believe that there are 
hardly any callosal fibres derived from this source,
The area from wh: the callosal fibres in the 
mid-brain, as I have formerly limited it, are essen =
tially derived is that of the <s>ascending <\s> ends of the 
1st & 2nd frontal, the <s>ascen <\s> upper 8/10 or thereabouts 
of the ascending frontal & parietal , and from the 
gyrus supra-marginalis anteriorly. The parts below 
a horizontal line <s>corresponding <\s> drawn across the operculum 
antero posteriorly about half an inch above its margin 
I believe do not contribute to any degree in the middle third 
of the hemisphere, to the construction of the corpus call =
=osum
